title: Fix auto-import creating duplicates instead of updating issues
description:
ROOT CAUSE: server_export_import_auto.go line 221 uses ResolveCollisions: true for ALL auto-imports. This is wrong.

Problem:
- ResolveCollisions is for branch merges (different issues with same ID)
- Auto-import should UPDATE existing issues, not create duplicates
- Every git pull creates NEW duplicate issues with different IDs
- Two agents ping-pong creating endless duplicates

Evidence:
- 31 duplicate groups found (bd duplicates)
- bd-236-246 are duplicates of bd-224-235
- Both agents keep pulling and creating more duplicates
- JSONL file grows endlessly with duplicates

The Fix:
Change checkAndAutoImportIfStale in server_export_import_auto.go:
- Remove ResolveCollisions: true (line 221)
- Use normal import logic that updates existing issues by ID
- Only use ResolveCollisions for explicit bd import --resolve-collisions

Impact: Critical - makes beads unusable for multi-agent workflows
acceptance_criteria:
- Auto-import does NOT create duplicates when pulling git changes
- Existing issues are updated in-place by ID match
- No ping-pong commits between agents
- Test: two agents updating same issue should NOT create duplicates
- bd duplicates shows 0 groups after fix

title: Daemon fails to auto-import after git pull updates JSONL
description:
After git pull updates .beads/issues.jsonl, daemon doesn't automatically re-import changes, causing stale data to be shown until next sync cycle (up to 5 minutes).

Reproduction:
1. Repo A: Close issues, export, commit, push
2. Repo B: git pull (successfully updates .beads/issues.jsonl)
3. bd show <issue> shows OLD status from daemon's SQLite db
4. JSONL on disk has correct new status

Root cause: Daemon sync cycle runs on timer (5min). When user manually runs git pull, daemon doesn't detect JSONL was updated externally and continues serving stale data from SQLite.

Impact:
- High for AI agents using beads in git workflows
- Breaks fundamental git-as-source-of-truth model
- Confusing UX: git log shows commit, bd shows old state
- Data consistency issues between JSONL and daemon

See WYVERN_SYNC_ISSUE.md for full analysis.
design:
Three possible solutions:

Option 1: Auto-detect and re-import (recommended)
- Before serving any bd command, check if .beads/issues.jsonl mtime > last import time
- If newer, auto-import before processing request
- Fast check, minimal overhead

Option 2: File watcher in daemon
- Daemon watches .beads/issues.jsonl for mtime changes
- Auto-imports when file changes
- More complex, requires file watching infrastructure

Option 3: Explicit sync command
- User runs `bd sync` after git pull
- Manual, error-prone, defeats automation

Recommended: Option 1 (auto-detect) + Option 3 (explicit sync) as fallback.
acceptance_criteria:
1. After git pull updates .beads/issues.jsonl, next bd command sees fresh data
2. No manual import or daemon restart required
3. Performance impact < 10ms per command (mtime check is fast)
4. Works in both daemon and non-daemon modes
5. Test: Two repo clones, update in one, pull in other, verify immediate sync
notes:
**Fixed in v0.21.2!**

The daemon auto-import is fully implemented:
- internal/autoimport package handles staleness detection
- internal/importer package provides shared import logic (used by both CLI and daemon)
- daemon's checkAndAutoImportIfStale() calls autoimport.AutoImportIfNewer()
- importFunc uses importer.ImportIssues() with auto-rename enabled
- All tests passing

The critical data corruption bug is FIXED:
âœ… After git pull, daemon detects JSONL is newer (mtime check)
âœ… Daemon auto-imports before serving requests
âœ… No stale data served
âœ… No data loss in multi-agent workflows

Verification needed: Run two-repo test to confirm end-to-end behavior.

notes:
PR #203 updated with cleaner implementation: https://github.com/steveyegge/beads/pull/203

## Final Implementation

Cleanest possible approach - no internal helper methods needed:

**Design:**
- `GetDependenciesWithMetadata()` / `GetDependentsWithMetadata()` - canonical implementations with full SQL query
- `GetDependencies()` / `GetDependents()` - thin wrappers that strip metadata for backward compat
- `scanIssuesWithDependencyType()` - shared helper for scanning rows with dependency type

**Benefits:**
- Single source of truth - the `...WithMetadata()` methods ARE the implementation
- Eliminated ~139 lines of duplicated SQL and scanning code
- All tests passing (14 dependency-related tests)
- Backward compatible
- dependency_type field appears correctly in JSON output

**Note on scan helpers:**
The duplication between `scanIssues()` and `scanIssuesWithDependencyType()` is necessary because they handle different SQL result shapes (16 vs 17 columns). This is justified as they serve fundamentally different purposes based on query structure.

title: Fix bd doctor hash ID detection for short all-numeric hashes
description:
bd doctor incorrectly flags hash-based IDs as sequential when they are short (3-4 chars) and all-numeric (e.g., pf-158).

Root cause: isHashID() in cmd/bd/migrate_hash_ids.go:328-358 uses faulty heuristic:
- For IDs < 5 chars, only returns true if contains letters
- But base36 hash IDs can be 3+ chars and all-numeric (MinLength: 3)
- Example: pf-158 is valid hash ID but flagged as sequential

Fix: Check multiple IDs (10-20 samples) instead of single-ID pattern matching:
- Sample IDs across database 
- Check majority pattern (sequential vs hash format)
- Sequential: 1-4 digits (bd-1, bd-2...)
- Hash: 3-8 chars base36 (pf-158, pf-3s9...)

Impact: False positive warnings in bd doctor output

title: Add batch deletion command for issues
description:
Support deleting multiple issues efficiently instead of one at a time.

**Use Cases:**
- Cleaning up duplicate/spam issues (e.g., bd-83 to bd-93 watchdog spam)
- Removing test-only issues after feature removal
- Bulk cleanup of obsolete/spurious bugs
- Renumbering prep: delete ranges before compaction

**Proposed Syntax Options:**

**Option 1: Multiple IDs as arguments**
```bash
bd delete vc-1 vc-2 vc-3 --force
bd delete vc-{1..20} --force  # Shell expansion
```

**Option 2: Read from file (RECOMMENDED)**
```bash
bd delete --from-file deletions.txt --force --dry-run  # Preview
bd delete --from-file deletions.txt --force            # Execute
# File format: one issue ID per line
```

**Option 3: Query-based deletion**
```bash
bd delete --where "priority=3 AND type=chore" --force
bd delete --label test-only --force
bd delete --prefix bd- --status open --force
```

**Must-Have Features:**

1. **Dry-run mode**: `--dry-run` to preview what would be deleted
   - Show issue IDs, titles, dependency counts
   - Warn about issues with dependents

2. **Dependency handling**:
   - `--cascade`: Delete dependents recursively
   - `--force`: Delete even if dependents exist (orphans them)
   - Default: Fail if any issue has dependents

3. **Summary output**:
   ```
   Deleted 162 issues
   Removed 347 dependencies
   Removed 89 labels
   Orphaned 5 issues (use --cascade to delete)
   ```

4. **Transaction safety**: All-or-nothing for file/query input
   - Either all deletions succeed or none do
   - Rollback on error

**Nice-to-Have Features:**

1. **Interactive confirmation** for large batches (>10 issues)
   ```
   About to delete 162 issues. Continue? [y/N]
   (Use --force to skip confirmation)
   ```

2. **Progress indicator** for large batches (>50 deletions)
   ```
   Deleting issues... [####------] 42/162 (26%)
   ```

3. **Undo support**:
   ```bash
   bd undelete --last-batch  # Restore from snapshots
   bd undelete bd-83        # Restore single issue
   ```

**Implementation Notes:**

- Leverage existing `DeleteIssue()` in storage layer
- Wrap in transaction for atomicity
- Consider adding `DeleteIssues(ctx, []string)` for efficiency
- May need to query dependents before deletion
- File format should support comments (#) and blank lines
- JSON output mode should list all deleted IDs

**Example Workflow:**
```bash
# Identify issues to delete
bd list --label test-only --json | jq -r '.[].id' > /tmp/delete.txt

# Preview deletion
bd delete --from-file /tmp/delete.txt --dry-run

# Execute with cascade
bd delete --from-file /tmp/delete.txt --cascade --force

# Verify
bd stats
```

**Security Considerations:**
- Require explicit `--force` flag to prevent accidents
- Warn when deleting issues with dependencies
- Log deletions to audit trail
- Consider requiring confirmation for >100 deletions even with --force

**Requested by:** Another agent during cleanup of bd-83 to bd-93 watchdog spam
notes:
Fixed critical issues found in code review:
1. Dry-run mode now properly uses dryRun parameter instead of deleting data
2. Text references are pre-collected before deletion so they update correctly
3. Added orphan deduplication to prevent duplicate IDs
4. Added rows.Err() checks in all row iteration loops
5. Updated defer to ignore rollback error per Go best practices

title: Daemon crashes silently on RPC query after startup
description:
The daemon fails to handle 'show' RPC commands when:
1) JSONL is newer than database (needs import)
2) git pull fails due to uncommitted changes

Symptoms:
- Daemon appears to run (ps shows process)
- 'bd list' and other commands work fine  
- 'bd show <id>' returns "failed to read response: EOF"
- No panic or error logged in daemon.log

Root cause likely: auto-import deadlock or state corruption when import is blocked by git conflicts.

Workaround: 
- Restart daemon after syncing git state (commit/push changes)
- OR use --no-daemon flag for all commands

The panic recovery added in server_lifecycle_conn.go:183 didn't catch any panics, confirming this isn't a panic-based crash.
notes: Root cause found and fixed: Two bugs - (1) nil pointer check missing in handleShow causing panic, (2) double JSON encoding in show.go ID resolution. Both fixed. bd show now works with daemon.

Actual: Inverted comparison logic

- bd-96 was 'Fix bool pointer literal errors' (in_progress)

This is data loss - active work (bd-96 was in_progress) was silently deleted.
design:
Renumber should handle mixed prefixes:
1. Group issues by prefix
2. Renumber each group independently
3. Or: fail if multiple prefixes detected with helpful error
4. Or: add --prefix flag to specify which prefix to renumber

Never silently delete issues.
acceptance_criteria: Renumber preserves all issues regardless of prefix, or fails with clear error message
notes: Not a bug - mixed prefixes in one database is user error. Filed bd-110 for proper validation instead.

title: Validate issue prefix matches database prefix on create
description:
Users can accidentally create issues with the wrong prefix (e.g., creating 'bd-95' in the vc tracker instead of the beads tracker).

This causes problems:
- Issues appear in wrong project
- Renumbering silently removes them (correct behavior, but surprising)
- Confusion about which tracker owns the issue

Evidence from vc project:
- bd-95 and bd-96 were created in ~/src/vc/vc/.beads/vc.db (should use vc- prefix)
- These were silently removed during renumbering (working as intended)
- But user didn't realize they were in wrong database until too late

Root cause: User was in vc directory but created issues with bd- prefix, probably because they were beads-related fixes.
design:
Options:

1. **Strict validation (recommended)**:
   - Detect database prefix from existing issues or .beads/*.db filename
   - Reject 'bd create' if prefix doesn't match
   - Error: 'This database uses prefix vc-, but you tried to create bd-X. Use --force to override.'

2. **Auto-correct prefix**:
   - 'bd create' in vc database always uses vc- prefix regardless of what user intended
   - Warning: 'Auto-corrected prefix from bd- to vc-'

3. **Multiple prefix support**:
   - Allow multiple prefixes per database
   - Group by prefix during renumbering
   - Complexity not worth it

Prefer option 1 - fail fast with clear error.
acceptance_criteria: Creating an issue with wrong prefix fails with helpful error message explaining the mismatch

title: bd delete panics with nil pointer when daemon is running
description:
When the daemon is running (daemonClient != nil), the delete command panics with nil pointer dereference because it tries to use the global store variable which is nil.

The PersistentPreRun in main.go returns early when daemon is connected (line 104), skipping store initialization. But delete.go:92 calls store.GetIssue() without checking if store is nil or if it should use daemonClient instead.

Reproduction:
1. Start daemon: bd daemon start
2. Try to delete: bd delete bd-130 --force
3. Panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference

Root cause: Missing daemon fallback pattern that other commands use (see ready.go:135-143)

title: Improve error handling in dependency removal during remapping
description: In updateDependencyReferences(), RemoveDependency errors are caught and ignored with continue (line 392). Comment says 'if dependency doesn't exist' but this catches ALL errors including real failures. Should check error type with errors.Is(err, ErrDependencyNotFound) and only ignore not-found errors, returning other errors properly.

title: Daemon doesn't clean up stale socket on startup
description:
If daemon crashes, the socket file remains. Next startup fails with 'address already in use' even though no process is listening.

Fix: Before starting RPC server, check if socket exists and PID file shows dead process - remove stale socket.

Lines 520-532 in daemon.go create socket but don't clean up stale ones.

title: Global daemon should warn/reject --auto-commit and --auto-push
description:
When user runs 'bd daemon --global --auto-commit', it's unclear which repo the daemon will commit to (especially after fixing bd-99 where global daemon won't open a DB).

Options:
1. Warn and ignore the flags in global mode
2. Error out with clear message

Line 87-91 already checks autoPush, but should skip check entirely for global mode. Add user-friendly messaging about flag incompatibility.

title: Socket permissions should be 0600 for security
description:
Unix sockets should use 0600 permissions to prevent other users from connecting.

Currently:
- Global .beads dir uses 0700 (good) 
- Local .beads dir uses 0700 (good)
- But socket itself may inherit default perms

Verify rpc.NewServer creates socket with 0600, or set umask/explicit perms.

title: Global daemon still requires database and runs sync loop
description:
The --global flag skips git repo check (line 80) but runDaemonLoop still calls FindDatabasePath (line 500-507) and opens a store (line 512). It also runs the single-repo sync loop (lines 563-620).

Oracle correctly identified this violates the spec: 'Don't require being in a git repo when --global is used'.

Fix: Global mode should skip DB open and sync loop entirely. It should be a pure RPC router that uses per-request context (bd-92) to route to the correct repo's DB.

Impact: Users can't run 'bd daemon --global' outside a repo, defeating the purpose.

title: bd ready doesn't show epics/tasks ready to close when all children complete
description: The 'bd ready' command doesn't show epics that have all children complete as ready work. Example: vc-30 (epic) blocks 4 children - 3 are closed, 1 is in_progress. The epic itself should be reviewable/closable but doesn't show in ready work. Similarly, vc-61 (epic, in_progress) depends on vc-48 (closed) but doesn't show as ready. Expected: epics with all dependencies satisfied should show as ready to review/close. Actual: 'bd ready' returns 'no ready work' even though multiple epics are completable.
acceptance_criteria: bd ready shows epics/tasks that have all dependencies satisfied (even if status is in_progress), allowing user to review and close them

title: CleanupStaleInstances() never called in production - orphaned claims accumulate
description: The CleanupStaleInstances() method exists in storage layer but is never called in production code. This means dead executors leave orphaned claims that block work forever. Example: vc-106 claimed by executor that died 2 hours ago, still shows in_progress with execution_state record. Need to: 1) Add periodic cleanup to executor main loop (every 5 min?), 2) Make cleanup also release claimed issues (delete execution_state AND reset status to open), 3) Add comment explaining why released.
design: Add background goroutine in executor that calls CleanupStaleInstances() every 5 minutes. When marking instance stopped, also query for all issues claimed by that instance and release them (delete execution_state, set status=open, add event comment).
acceptance_criteria: Dead executors automatically release their claims within 5-10 minutes of going stale, issues return to open status and become available for re-execution

title: releaseIssueWithError() deletes execution_state but leaves status as in_progress
description: When an executor hits an error and releases an issue via releaseIssueWithError(), it deletes the execution_state but leaves the issue status as in_progress. This means the issue drops out of ready work but has no active executor. Expected: releasing should reset status to open so the issue becomes available again. Current code in conversation.go just calls ReleaseIssue() which only deletes execution_state.
design: Update releaseIssueWithError() to also update issue status back to open. Or create a new ReleaseAndReopen() method that does both atomically in a transaction.
acceptance_criteria: Issues released due to errors automatically return to open status and show in bd ready

title: Database import silently fails when daemon version != CLI version
Use safer placeholder pattern in replaceIDReferences
description: Currently uses bd-313 which could theoretically collide with user text. Use a truly unique placeholder like null bytes: \x00REMAP\x00_0_\x00 which are unlikely to appear in normal text. Located in collision.go:324. Very low probability issue but worth fixing for completeness.

title: Add 'bd stale' command to show orphaned claims and dead executors
description: Need visibility into orphaned claims - issues stuck in_progress with execution_state but executor is dead/stopped. Add command to show: 1) All issues with execution_state where executor status=stopped or last_heartbeat > threshold, 2) Executor instance details (when died, how long claimed), 3) Option to auto-release them. Makes manual recovery easier until auto-cleanup (bd-118) is implemented.
design: Query: SELECT i.*, ei.status, ei.last_heartbeat FROM issues i JOIN issue_execution_state ies ON i.id = ies.issue_id JOIN executor_instances ei ON ies.executor_instance_id = ei.instance_id WHERE ei.status='stopped' OR ei.last_heartbeat < NOW() - threshold. Add --release flag to auto-release all found issues.
acceptance_criteria: bd stale shows orphaned claims, bd stale --release cleans them up

title: Bias ready work towards recent issues before oldest-first
description: Currently 'bd ready' shows oldest issues first (by created_at). This can bury recently discovered work that might be more relevant. Propose a hybrid approach: show issues from the past 1-2 days first (sorted by priority), then fall back to oldest-first for older issues. This keeps fresh discoveries visible while still surfacing old forgotten work.

title: Fix nil pointer dereference in renumber command
description: The 'bd renumber' command crashes with a nil pointer dereference at renumber.go:52 because store is nil. The command doesn't properly handle daemon/direct mode initialization like other commands do. Error occurs on both --dry-run and --force modes.

title: Add storage cache eviction policy to daemon
description:
Daemon caches DB connections forever in storageCache map (server.go:29). For users with 50+ repos, this causes memory leaks and file descriptor exhaustion.

Need LRU cache with:
- Max size limit (default: 50 repos)
- TTL-based eviction (default: 30min idle)
- Periodic cleanup goroutine

Location: internal/rpc/server.go:29-40
design:
Add StorageCacheEntry struct with lastAccess timestamp.

Implement evictStaleStorage() method that runs every 5 minutes to close connections idle >30min.

Add max cache size enforcement (LRU eviction when full).

Make limits configurable via env vars:
- BEADS_DAEMON_MAX_CACHE_SIZE (default: 50)
- BEADS_DAEMON_CACHE_TTL (default: 30m)
acceptance_criteria:
- Cache evicts entries after 30min idle
- Cache respects max size limit
- Cleanup goroutine runs periodically
- Evicted storage connections are properly closed
- No resource leaks under sustained load
- Unit tests for eviction logic

title: Add daemon health check endpoint and probes
description:
Auto-start only checks socket existence, not daemon responsiveness. Daemon can be running but unresponsive (deadlock, hung DB). Users work in degraded direct mode without knowing why.

Need health check RPC operation that:
- Tests DB connectivity (1s timeout)
- Returns uptime, status, metrics
- Used by auto-start before connecting
- Enables monitoring/alerting

Location: internal/rpc/server.go, cmd/bd/main.go:100-108
design:
Add OpHealth RPC operation to protocol.

handleHealth() implementation:
- Quick DB ping with 1s timeout
- Return status, uptime, version
- Include basic metrics (connections, cache size)

Update TryConnect() to call Health() after socket connection:
- If health check fails, close connection and return nil
- Enables transparent failover to direct mode

Add 'bd daemon --health' CLI command for monitoring.
acceptance_criteria:
- Health check RPC endpoint works
- Returns structured health status
- Client uses health check before operations
- bd daemon --health command exists
- Unhealthy daemon triggers auto-restart or fallback
- Health check completes in <2 seconds

title: Add stale socket and crash recovery for daemon
description:
When daemon crashes (panic, OOM, signal), socket file remains and blocks new daemon start. Users must manually remove .beads/bd.sock.

Problems:
- Socket file remains after crash
- PID file remains (isDaemonRunning false positive)
- No automatic recovery
- Users get 'daemon already running' error

Location: cmd/bd/daemon.go, cmd/bd/main.go:221-311
design:
Improve stale detection in tryAutoStartDaemon():

1. If socket exists, try to connect
2. If connection fails â†’ stale socket, remove it
3. Also remove PID file and lock files
4. Retry daemon start

Add self-healing to daemon startup:
- On startup, check for stale PID files
- If PID in file doesn't exist, remove and continue
- Use exclusive file lock to prevent races

Optional: Add crash recovery watchdog that restarts daemon on exit.
acceptance_criteria:
- Stale sockets are automatically detected and removed
- Auto-start recovers from daemon crashes
- No manual intervention needed for crash recovery
- PID file management is robust
- Lock files prevent multiple daemon instances
- Tests for crash recovery scenarios
notes:
Oracle code review identified race conditions. Improvements made:
- Moved cleanup AFTER lock acquisition (prevents unlinking live sockets)
- Added PID liveness check before removing socket
- Added stale lock detection with retry
- Tightened directory permissions to 0700
- Improved socket readiness probing with short timeouts
- Made removeOldSocket() ignore ENOENT errors

Changes eliminate race where socket could be removed during daemon startup window.

title: Add lifecycle management for beads-mcp processes
description:
MCP server processes accumulate without cleanup. Each tool invocation spawns a new Python process that lingers after Claude disconnects.

Observed: 6+ beads-mcp processes running simultaneously.

Problems:
- No parent-child relationship tracking
- No cleanup on MCP client disconnect
- Processes leak over days of use
- Could accumulate hundreds of processes

Location: integrations/beads-mcp/src/beads_mcp/server.py
design:
Add proper cleanup handlers to MCP server:

1. Register atexit handler to close daemon connections
2. Handle SIGTERM/SIGINT for graceful shutdown
3. Close daemon client in cleanup()
4. Remove any temp files

Optional improvements:
- Track active connections to daemon
- Implement connection pooling
- Add process timeout/TTL
- Log lifecycle events for debugging

Example:
import atexit
import signal

def cleanup():
    # Close daemon connections
    # Remove temp files
    pass

atexit.register(cleanup)
signal.signal(signal.SIGTERM, lambda s, f: cleanup())
acceptance_criteria:
- MCP processes clean up on exit
- Daemon connections are properly closed
- No process leaks after repeated use
- Signal handlers work correctly
- Cleanup runs on normal and abnormal exit
- Test with multiple concurrent MCP invocations

title: Add global daemon auto-start support
description:
Auto-start only works for local daemon. Users with multiple repos must manually run 'bd daemon --global'.

Problems:
- No detection of whether global daemon is preferable

- Manual setup required

Add heuristics to shouldUseGlobalDaemon():

1. Count .beads repos under home directory
2. If >3 repos found, prefer global daemon
3. Check BEADS_PREFER_GLOBAL_DAEMON env var
4. Check config file preference

Update tryAutoStartDaemon() to:
- Use shouldUseGlobalDaemon() to pick mode
- Pass --global flag when appropriate
- Log decision for debugging

Add migration helper:
- Detect running local daemon
- Suggest switching to global if multi-repo detected
- bd daemon --migrate-to-global command
acceptance_criteria:
- Auto-start uses global daemon when appropriate
- Multi-repo detection works correctly
- Users can configure preference
- Migration path is smooth
- Both local and global auto-start work
- Documentation updated

title: Improve daemon fallback visibility and user feedback
description:
When daemon is unavailable, bd silently falls back to direct mode. Users don't know:
- That daemon exists
- Why auto-start failed
- That they're in degraded mode
- How to fix it

This creates confusion for multi-repo users who get slower performance without explanation.

Location: cmd/bd/main.go:98-130
design:
Add visibility at multiple levels:

1. Debug logging (existing BD_DEBUG):
   - Already shows daemon connection attempts
   - Add auto-start success/failure

2. Verbose mode (BD_VERBOSE):
   - Show warning when falling back
   - Suggest 'bd daemon --status' to check

3. Status indicator:
   - Add daemon status to all commands when --json
   - Example: {"daemon_status": "healthy", "daemon_type": "local", ...}

4. Explicit status command:
   - bd daemon --status shows detailed info
   - Shows whether daemon is running/healthy/unavailable

5. Helpful error messages:
   - When auto-start fails repeatedly
   - When falling back after health check failure
   - With actionable next steps
acceptance_criteria:
- Users can see daemon status easily
- Fallback warnings are helpful not noisy
- JSON output includes daemon status
- Error messages are actionable
- Documentation explains status indicators
- bd daemon --status command works

title: Add version compatibility checks for daemon RPC protocol
description:
Client (bd CLI) and daemon may be different versions after upgrade. This causes:
- Missing features (newer CLI, older daemon)
- Protocol mismatches (older CLI, newer daemon)
- Silent failures or confusing errors
- No guidance to restart daemon

Location: internal/rpc/protocol.go, internal/rpc/client.go
design:
Add version field to RPC protocol:

1. Add ClientVersion to Request struct
2. Populate from Version constant in client
3. Server checks compatibility in handleRequest()

Compatibility rules:
- Major version must match
- Minor version backward compatible
- Patch version always compatible

On mismatch:
- Return clear error message
- Suggest 'bd daemon --stop && bd daemon'
- Log version info for debugging

Add to ping/health response:
- Server version
- Protocol version
- Compatibility info

Add bd version --daemon command to check running daemon version.
acceptance_criteria:
- Version field in RPC protocol
- Server validates client version
- Clear error messages on mismatch
- Health check returns version info
- bd version --daemon command works
- Documentation on version policy
- Tests for version compatibility

title: Add comprehensive tests for show.go commands (show, update, edit, close)
description:
Need to add tests for cmd/bd/show.go which contains show, update, edit, and close commands.

**Challenge**: The existing test patterns use rootCmd.SetArgs() and rootCmd.Execute(), but the global `store` variable needs to match what the commands use. Initial attempt created tests that failed with "no issue found" because the test's store instance wasn't the same as the command's store.

**Files to test**:
- show.go (contains showCmd, updateCmd, editCmd, closeCmd)

**Coverage needed**:
- show command (single issue, multiple issues, JSON output, with dependencies, with labels, with compaction)
- update command (status, priority, title, assignee, description, multiple fields, multiple issues)
- edit command (requires $EDITOR, may need mocking)
- close command (single issue, multiple issues, with reason, JSON output)

**Test approach**:
1. Study working test patterns in init_test.go, list_test.go, etc.
2. Ensure BEADS_NO_DAEMON=1 is set
3. Properly initialize database with bd init
4. Use the command's global store, not a separate instance
5. May need to reset global state between tests

**Success criteria**: 
- All test functions pass
- Coverage for show.go increases significantly
- Tests follow existing patterns in cmd/bd/*_test.go

title: Implement full cross-type cycle prevention in AddDependency
description: Expand cycle prevention in AddDependency to check for cycles across ALL dependency types, not just 'blocks'. Currently only 'blocks' type dependencies are checked for cycles, allowing cross-type circular dependencies to form (e.g., A blocks B, B parent-child A). This can cause semantic confusion and is a maintenance hazard for future operations that traverse dependencies.
design:
Implementation approach:
1. Modify the cycle check in AddDependency (postgres.go:559-599)
2. Remove the 'type = blocks' filter from the recursive CTE
3. Check for cycles regardless of dependency type being added
4. Return a clear error message indicating which types form the cycle

Trade-offs to consider:
- This is more mathematically correct (no cycles in dependency DAG)
- May break legitimate use cases where cross-type cycles are intentional
- Need to evaluate whether ANY cross-type cycles are valid in practice
- Alternative: make this configurable with a --allow-cycle flag

Before implementing, should investigate:
- Are there legitimate reasons for cross-type cycles?
- What's the performance impact on large graphs (1000+ issues)?
- Should certain type combinations be allowed to cycle?
acceptance_criteria:
- AddDependency prevents cycles across all dependency types, not just 'blocks'
- Clear error message when cycle would be created, including dependency types
- All existing tests pass
- Performance benchmarked on large dependency graphs (100+ issues)
- Decision documented on whether to add --allow-cycle flag or exception rules

title: Add resource limits to daemon (connections, cache, memory)
description:
Daemon has no resource limits. Under heavy load or attack, it could:

- Use unbounded memory

Need limits for:

design:
Add resource tracking to Server:

type Server struct {

Use semaphore pattern for connection limiting:

title: Add log rotation for daemon.log
description:
daemon.log grows forever without rotation. With sync every 5 minutes:

- No size limit
- No cleanup
- Eventually fills disk

Need automatic log rotation with:

Location: cmd/bd/daemon.go:455
design:
Use lumberjack library for rotation:

import "gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack.v2"

logF := &lumberjack.Logger{
    Filename:   logPath,
    MaxSize:    10,  // MB
    MaxBackups: 3,
    MaxAge:     7,   // days

}

Make configurable via env vars:
- BEADS_DAEMON_LOG_MAX_SIZE (default: 10MB)
- BEADS_DAEMON_LOG_MAX_BACKUPS (default: 3)
- BEADS_DAEMON_LOG_MAX_AGE (default: 7 days)

Add to daemon status output:
- Current log size
- Number of archived logs

acceptance_criteria:
- Log rotation works automatically
- Old logs are compressed
- Retention policy enforced
- Configuration via env vars works
- Log size stays bounded
- No log data loss during rotation
- Documentation updated

title: Daemon production readiness
description:
Make beads daemon production-ready for long-running use, multi-repo deployments, and resilient operation.

Current state: Good foundation, works well for development

Gap areas:
1. Resource management (cache eviction, limits)
2. Health monitoring and crash recovery
3. Process lifecycle management
4. User experience (visibility, feedback)
5. Operational concerns (logging, metrics)

Success criteria:
- Can run for weeks without restart
- Handles 50+ repositories efficiently
- Recovers from crashes automatically
- Users understand daemon status
- Observable and debuggable
acceptance_criteria:
All child issues completed:
- P0 issues: Storage cache, health checks, crash recovery, MCP cleanup
- P1 issues: Global auto-start, visibility, version checks
- P2 issues: Resource limits, telemetry, log rotation

Validation:

title: Refactor import logic to eliminate duplication between manual and auto-import
description:
The import logic is duplicated in two places:
1. cmd/bd/import.go (manual 'bd import' command)
2. cmd/bd/main.go:autoImportIfNewer() (auto-import after git pull)

Both have nearly identical code for:
- Reading and parsing JSONL
- Type-asserting store to *sqlite.SQLiteStorage (where we just fixed a bug twice)
- Opening direct SQLite connection when using daemon mode
- Detecting collisions with sqlite.DetectCollisions()
- Scoring and remapping collisions
- Importing issues, dependencies, and labels

**Problems:**
- Bugs must be fixed in two places (we just did this for daemon mode)
- Features must be implemented twice
- Tests must cover both code paths
- Harder to maintain and keep in sync
- Higher risk of divergence over time

**Proposed solution:**
Extract a shared function that handles the core import logic:

```go
// importIssues handles the core import logic used by both manual and auto-import
func importIssues(ctx context.Context, dbPath string, store storage.Storage, 
                  issues []*types.Issue, opts ImportOptions) (*ImportResult, error) {
    // Handle SQLite store detection/creation for daemon mode
    // Detect collisions
    // Score and remap if needed
    // Import issues, dependencies, labels
    // Return result
}
```

Both import.go and autoImportIfNewer() would call this shared function with their specific options.

**Benefits:**
- Single source of truth for import logic
- Bugs fixed once
- Easier to test
- Easier to extend with new import features
- Less code overall

**Current state:**
- âœ… Manual import uses importIssuesCore() (commit 790233f)
- âŒ Auto-import still has duplicated logic (lines 618-915 in main.go)

**Duplication includes:**
- SQLite store detection/creation for daemon mode (fixed in 790233f)
- Collision detection with sqlite.DetectCollisions()
- Scoring and remapping collisions
- Importing issues (update existing, create new)
- Importing dependencies

**Benefits of completing this:**

**Implementation:**

opts := ImportOptions{

title: Fix SQL timestamp scanning error on macOS (GH-88)
description:
User reported 'Scan error on column index 11, name created_at: unsupported Scan, storing driver.Value type string into type *time.Time' on macOS 13.5. 

Root cause: modernc.org/sqlite driver doesn't recognize mattn-style DSN parameters like _journal_mode=WAL and _foreign_keys=ON. When these are present, it ignores _time_format=sqlite on some platforms, causing DATETIME columns to be returned as strings instead of time.Time.

Fix: Use modernc's native _pragma syntax for all options:
- Changed _journal_mode=WAL to _pragma=journal_mode(WAL)
- Changed _foreign_keys=ON to _pragma=foreign_keys(ON)

This ensures _time_format=sqlite is properly recognized and DATETIME columns are automatically parsed to time.Time.

title: Renumber command fails with foreign key constraint error
description: When running 'bd renumber --force' after deleting issues, the command fails with: 'failed to rename bd-19 to temp ID: failed to update issue ID: constraint failed: FOREIGN KEY constraint failed (787)'. This suggests the renumber implementation doesn't properly handle foreign key constraints during the ID swap process. May need to disable foreign keys temporarily or use a different renumbering strategy.
notes: Deeper investigation: All child tables (dependencies, labels, events, dirty_issues, issue_snapshots, compaction_snapshots, comments) have FK constraints to issues(id) ON DELETE CASCADE. When renumbering tries to UPDATE issues SET id = temp-uuid WHERE id = bd-49, the FK checks fire immediately despite PRAGMA foreign_keys = OFF being called. Issue might be that Go sql.DB connection pooling means the PRAGMA isn't applied to the actual connection doing the UPDATE. Testing with explicit connection (s.db.Conn()) to ensure PRAGMA sticks.

title: bd uses wrong default prefix when database filename indicates different prefix
description: When creating issues without explicit --id flag, bd defaults to 'bd-' prefix even when the database filename and existing issues use a different prefix (e.g., 'wy-').
design:
## Bug Report

**Environment:**
- bd version: 0.9.11 (based on metadata)
- Database: .beads/wy-.db
- Directory: /Users/stevey/ai/flutter/wyvern

**Observed Behavior:**
When running `bd create task "title"` without --id flag, new issues get assigned `bd-*` IDs even though:
- Database filename is `.beads/wy-.db` (implies wy- prefix)
- All existing issues use `wy-*` prefix (wy-1 through wy-77)
- No prefix metadata stored in database

**Evidence:**
```sql
sqlite3 .beads/wy-.db "SELECT * FROM issue_counters;"
wy|72
bd|29
```

The bd counter was incremented when I accidentally created bd-23 through bd-29 (now deleted).

**Expected Behavior:**
bd should derive the default prefix from:
1. Database filename (`wy-.db` â†’ `wy-` prefix), OR
2. Most recently used prefix in the database, OR  
3. Prefix stored in metadata table

According to `bd init --help`:
> -p, --prefix string   Issue prefix (default: current directory name)

But database filename convention appears to be `<prefix>.db`, so wy-.db should mean wy- is the intended prefix.

**Workaround:**
Use explicit `--id` flag: `bd create task "title" --id wy-73`

**Reproduction:**
```bash
# In a directory with .beads/wy-.db containing wy-* issues
bd create task "test"
# Creates bd-* issue instead of wy-* issue
```

**Suggested Fix:**
1. Store the intended prefix in metadata table during `bd init`
2. When creating issues, check metadata for preferred prefix
3. Fallback to extracting prefix from database filename
4. Last resort: use directory name

**Related Code:**
Likely in issue counter/ID generation logic where new IDs are assigned.

title: bd sync false positive: conflict detection triggers on JSON-encoded angle brackets in issue content
description:
The bd sync --import-only command incorrectly detects conflict markers when issue descriptions contain the text '<<<<<<<' or '>>>>>>>' as legitimate content (e.g., documentation about git conflict markers).

**Reproduction:**
1. Create issue with design field containing: 'Read file, extract <<<<<<< / ======= / >>>>>>> markers'
2. Export to JSONL (gets JSON-encoded as \u003c\u003c\u003c...)
3. Commit and push
4. Pull from remote
5. bd sync --import-only fails with: 'Git conflict markers detected in JSONL file'

**Root cause:**
The conflict detection appears to decode JSON before checking for conflict markers, causing false positives when issue content legitimately contains these strings.

**Expected behavior:**
Conflict detection should only trigger on actual git conflict markers (literal '<<<<<<<' bytes in the raw file), not on JSON-encoded content within issue fields.

**Test case:**
VC project at ~/src/dave/vc has vc-85 'JSONL Conflict Parser' which documents conflict parsing and triggers this bug.

**Suggested fixes:**
1. Only scan for literal '<<<<<<<' bytes (not decoded JSON content)
2. Parse JSONL first and only flag unparseable lines
3. Check git merge state (git status) to confirm actual conflict
4. Add --skip-conflict-check flag for override

title: Implement storage driver interface for pluggable backends
description:
Create abstraction layer for storage to support multiple backends (SQLite, Postgres, Turso, in-memory testing, etc.).

**Current state:** All storage logic hardcoded to SQLite in internal/storage/sqlite/sqlite.go

**Proposed design:**

```go
// internal/storage/storage.go
type Store interface {
    // Issue CRUD
    CreateIssue(issue *Issue) error
    GetIssue(id string) (*Issue, error)
    UpdateIssue(id string, updates *Issue) error
    DeleteIssue(id string) error
    ListIssues(filter *Filter) ([]*Issue, error)
    
    // Dependencies
    AddDependency(from, to string, depType DependencyType) error
    RemoveDependency(from, to string, depType DependencyType) error
    GetDependencies(id string) ([]*Dependency, error)
    
    // Counters, stats
    GetNextID(prefix string) (string, error)
    GetStats() (*Stats, error)
    
    Close() error
}
```

**Benefits:**
- Better testing (mock/in-memory stores)
- Future flexibility (Postgres, cloud APIs, etc.)
- Clean architecture (business logic decoupled from storage)
- Enable Turso or other backends without refactoring everything

**Implementation steps:**
1. Define Store interface in internal/storage/storage.go
2. Refactor SQLiteStore to implement interface
3. Update all commands to use interface, not concrete type
4. Add MemoryStore for testing
5. Add driver selection via config (storage.driver = sqlite|turso|postgres)
6. Update tests to use interface

**Note:** This is valuable even without adopting Turso. Good architecture practice.

**Context:** From GH issue #2 RFC evaluation. Driver interface is low-cost, high-value regardless of whether we add alternative backends.

Investigate bd export/import sync issue - database and JSONL out of sync
description:
Observed in VC repo: database has 1137 issues but beads.jsonl only has 309. Running 'bd export -o .beads/issues.jsonl' doesn't update the file. Running 'bd import' hangs indefinitely.

Reproduction context:
- VC repo: 1137 issues in DB, 309 in JSONL
- Created 4 new issues with bd create
- bd export didn't write them to JSONL
- bd import hung (possibly daemon lock conflict?)

Need to investigate:
1. Why export doesn't update JSONL when DB has more issues
2. Why import hangs
3. Daemon lock interaction with export/import
4. File path handling (issues.jsonl vs beads.jsonl)
design: Check export logic for silent failures, file locking, path resolution. Check import for blocking operations, daemon conflicts.
acceptance_criteria:
- Root cause of export not updating JSONL identified
- Root cause of import hanging identified  
- Fix implemented and verified
- Test coverage for sync scenarios
- Documentation updated if needed
notes:
## Root Cause Analysis

The issue was NOT about file path handling or export failing to update JSONL. The actual problem was:

**Import/Export hanging when daemon is running** due to SQLite lock contention:

1. When daemon is connected, `PersistentPreRun` in main.go returns early without initializing the `store` variable
2. Import/Export commands then tried to open the database directly with `sqlite.New(dbPath)` 
3. This blocked waiting for the database lock that the daemon already holds â†’ **HANGS INDEFINITELY**

## Solution Implemented

Modified both import.go and export.go to:
1. Detect when `daemonClient` is connected
2. Explicitly close the daemon connection before opening direct SQLite access
3. Added debug logging to help diagnose similar issues

This ensures import/export commands always run in direct mode, avoiding lock contention.

## File Path Handling

The file path confusion (issues.jsonl vs beads.jsonl) was a red herring. The code uses `filepath.Glob("*.jsonl")` which correctly finds ANY `.jsonl` file in `.beads/` directory, so both filenames work.

title: Investigate auto-export debounce not triggering
description:
Auto-export to JSONL did not trigger automatically after creating bd-33 and bd-17. Had to manually run 'bd export' to sync.

**Actual behavior:** Issues bd-33 and bd-17 were created but JSONL was not updated until manual 'bd export' was run.

**Investigation needed:**
1. Check if auto-flush goroutine is running
2. Verify debounce timer is being triggered on CreateIssue()
3. Check for errors/panics in background export
4. Verify auto-flush is enabled by default
5. Check if there's a race condition with shutdown

**Impact:** HIGH - Data loss risk if users create issues and don't realize they haven't synced to Git.

**Testing:**
```bash
# Create issue and wait 10 seconds
bd create "Test" -p 4
sleep 10
grep "Test" .beads/issues.jsonl  # Should find it

Investigate why test issues persist in database
description:
Test issues (bd-0do3, bd-cjxp, bd-phr2, etc.) keep appearing in ready/list output, cluttering real work. These appear to be leftover test data from test runs.

Need to investigate:
1. Why are test issues not being cleaned up after tests?
2. Are tests creating issues in the main database instead of test databases?
3. Should we add better test isolation or cleanup hooks?
4. Can we add a label/prefix to distinguish test issues from real issues?

These test issues have characteristics:
- Empty descriptions
- Generic titles like "Test issue 0", "Bug P0", "Issue to reopen with reason"
- Created around 2025-11-07 19:00-19:07
- Some assigned to test users like "alice", "bob", "testuser"
notes:
## Root Cause Analysis

**Problem**: Python MCP integration tests created test issues in production `.beads/beads.db` instead of isolated test databases.

**Evidence**:
- 29 test issues created on Nov 7, 2025 at 19:00-19:07
- Patterns: "Bug P0", "Test issue X", assignees "alice"/"bob"/"testuser"
- Git commit 0e8936b shows test issues committed to .beads/beads.jsonl
- Tests were being fixed for workspace isolation around the same time

**Why It Happened**:
1. Before commit 0e8936b, `test_client_lazy_initialization()` didn't set `BEADS_WORKING_DIR`
2. Tests fell back to discovering `.beads/` in the project root directory
3. Auto-sync committed test issues to production database

**Resolution**:
1. âœ… Closed 29 test pollution issues (bd-0do3, bd-cjxp, etc.)
2. âœ… Added `failIfProductionDatabase()` guard in Go test helpers
3. âœ… Added production pollution checks in RPC test setup
4. âœ… Created `conftest.py` with pytest safety checks for Python tests
5. âœ… Added `BEADS_TEST_MODE` env var to mark test execution
6. âœ… Tests now fail fast if they detect production database usage

**Prevention**:
- All test helper functions now verify database paths are in temp directories
- Python tests fail immediately if BEADS_DB points to production
- BEADS_TEST_MODE flag helps identify test vs production execution
- Clear error messages guide developers to use proper test isolation

**Files Modified**:
- cmd/bd/test_helpers_test.go - Added failIfProductionDatabase()
- internal/rpc/rpc_test.go - Added temp directory verification
- integrations/beads-mcp/tests/conftest.py - New file with pytest safeguards

title: Fix silent error handling in RPC response writing
description:
Marshal and write errors silently ignored in writeResponse, can send partial JSON and hang clients.

Location: internal/rpc/server_lifecycle_conn.go:228-232

Problem:
- json.Marshal error ignored - cyclic reference sends corrupt JSON
- Write error ignored - connection closed, no indication to caller  
- WriteByte error ignored - client hangs waiting for newline
- Flush error ignored - partial data buffered

Current code:
func (s *Server) writeResponse(writer *bufio.Writer, resp Response) {
    data, _ := json.Marshal(resp)  // Ignored!
    _, _ = writer.Write(data)      // Ignored!
    _ = writer.WriteByte('\n')     // Ignored!
    _ = writer.Flush()             // Ignored!
}

Solution: Return errors, handle in caller, close connection on error

Impact: Client hangs waiting for response; corrupt JSON sent

Effort: 1 hour

title: Fix N-way collision convergence
description:
Epic to fix the N-way collision convergence problem documented in n-way-collision-convergence.md.

## Problem Summary
The current collision resolution implementation works correctly for 2-way collisions but does not converge for 3-way (and by extension N-way) collisions. TestThreeCloneCollision demonstrates this with reproducible failures.

## Root Causes Identified
1. Pairwise resolution doesn't scale - each clone makes local decisions without global context
2. DetectCollisions modifies state during detection (line 83-86 in collision.go)
3. No remapping history - can't track transitive remap chains (test-1 â†’ test-2 â†’ test-3)
4. Import-time resolution is too late - happens after git merge

## Solution Architecture
Replace pairwise resolution with deterministic global N-way resolution using:
- Content-addressable identity (content hashing)
- Global collision resolution (sort all versions by hash)
- Read-only detection phase (separate from modification)

title: Enforce daemon singleton per workspace with file locking
description:
Agent in ~/src/wyvern discovered 4 simultaneous daemon processes running, causing infinite directory recursion (.beads/.beads/.beads/...). Each daemon used relative paths and created nested .beads/ directories.

Root cause: No singleton enforcement. Multiple `bd daemon` processes can start in same workspace.

Expected: One daemon per workspace (each workspace = separate .beads/ dir with bd.sock)
Actual: Multiple daemons can run simultaneously in same workspace

Note: Separate git clones = separate workspaces = separate daemons (correct). Git worktrees share .beads/ and have known limitations (documented, use --no-daemon).
design:
Use flock (file locking) on daemon socket or database file to enforce singleton:

1. On daemon start, attempt exclusive lock on .beads/bd.sock or .beads/daemon.lock
2. If lock held by another process, refuse to start (exit with clear error)
3. Hold lock for lifetime of daemon process
4. Release lock on daemon shutdown

Alternative: Use PID file with stale detection (check if PID is still running)

Implementation location: Daemon startup code in cmd/bd/ or internal/daemon/
acceptance_criteria:
1. Starting second daemon process in same workspace fails with clear error
2. Test: Start daemon, attempt second start, verify failure
3. Killing daemon releases lock, allowing new daemon to start
4. No infinite .beads/ directory recursion possible
5. Works correctly with auto-start mechanism
notes:
## Fix Summary

Successfully prevented the nested .beads/.beads/ recursion bug by implementing two safeguards:

1. **Path Canonicalization in FindDatabasePath()** (beads.go):
   - Added filepath.Abs() + filepath.EvalSymlinks() to normalize all database paths
   - Prevents relative path edge cases that create nested directories
   - Ensures all daemons see the same canonical path

2. **Nested Directory Detection** (daemon_lifecycle.go):
   - Added explicit check for ".beads/.beads" pattern in setupDaemonLock()
   - Fails fast with clear error message if nested structure detected
   - Provides user hints about proper usage

## Root Cause

The daemon lock (added Oct 22, 2025) correctly prevents simultaneous daemons in the SAME workspace. However, when BEADS_DB used a relative path (e.g., ".beads/beads.db") from inside the .beads directory, FindDatabasePath() would resolve it to a nested path creating a separate workspace:
- First daemon: /workspace/.beads/beads.db
- Second daemon from .beads/: /workspace/.beads/.beads/beads.db â† Different lock file!

## Testing

All acceptance criteria passed:
âœ… 1. Second daemon start fails with "daemon already running" error
âœ… 2. Killing daemon releases lock, new daemon can start  
âœ… 3. No infinite .beads/ recursion possible (tested nested BEADS_DB path)
âœ… 4. Works with auto-start mechanism

The fix addresses the edge case while maintaining the existing lock mechanism's correctness.

description: Create a `bd setup cursor` command that integrates Beads workflow into Cursor IDE via .cursorrules file. Unlike Claude Code (which has hooks), Cursor uses a static rules file to provide context to its AI.
design:
## Implementation

Create `cursor` subcommand in `cmd/bd/setup.go` that manages `.cursorrules` integration:

### Command Interface
```bash
bd setup cursor           # Install/update Cursor integration
bd setup cursor --check   # Verify .cursorrules has bd section
bd setup cursor --remove  # Remove bd section from .cursorrules
```

### Behavior

**If `.cursorrules` doesn't exist:**
- Create new file with complete bd rules template
- Mark sections for easy identification

**If `.cursorrules` exists:**
- Check if bd section already exists (look for marker comments)
- If not exists: append bd section
- If exists: update in place (preserve user customizations outside bd section)
- Backup original with `.cursorrules.backup` suffix

### .cursorrules Template

```markdown
# Beads Issue Tracking
# Auto-generated by 'bd setup cursor' - do not remove these markers
# BEGIN BEADS INTEGRATION

This project uses [Beads (bd)](https://github.com/steveyegge/beads) for issue tracking.

## Core Rules
- Track ALL work in bd (never use markdown TODOs or comment-based task lists)
- Use `bd ready` to find available work
- Use `bd create` to track new issues/tasks/bugs
- Use `bd sync` at end of session to sync with git remote
- Git hooks auto-sync on commit/merge

## Quick Reference
```bash
bd prime                              # Load complete workflow context
bd ready                              # Show issues ready to work (no blockers)
bd list --status=open                 # List all open issues
bd create --title="..." --type=task  # Create new issue
bd update <id> --status=in_progress  # Claim work
bd close <id>                         # Mark complete
bd dep <from> <to>                    # Add dependency (from blocks to)
bd sync                               # Sync with git remote
```

## Workflow
1. Check for ready work: `bd ready`
2. Claim an issue: `bd update <id> --status=in_progress`
3. Do the work
4. Mark complete: `bd close <id>`
5. Sync: `bd sync` (or let git hooks handle it)

## Context Loading
Run `bd prime` to get complete workflow documentation in AI-optimized format (~1-2k tokens).

For detailed docs: see AGENTS.md, QUICKSTART.md, or run `bd --help`

# END BEADS INTEGRATION
```

### Detection Logic

```go
func setupCursor() error {
    cursorRulesPath := ".cursorrules"
    
    // Check if file exists
    content, err := os.ReadFile(cursorRulesPath)
    if err != nil {
        if os.IsNotExist(err) {
            // Create new file
            return createCursorRules(cursorRulesPath)
        }
        return err
    }
    
    // Check if bd section exists
    if hasBeadsSection(string(content)) {
        // Update existing section
        return updateBeadsSection(cursorRulesPath, string(content))
    } else {
        // Append new section
        return appendBeadsSection(cursorRulesPath, string(content))
    }
}

func hasBeadsSection(content string) bool {
    return strings.Contains(content, "BEGIN BEADS INTEGRATION")
}
```

## Files
- `cmd/bd/setup.go` - Add cursor subcommand
- `cmd/bd/setup_cursor.go` - Cursor-specific logic
- `cmd/bd/setup_cursor_test.go` - Tests
- Template stored as Go string constant

## Differences from Claude Setup

| Aspect | Claude | Cursor |
|--------|--------|--------|
| **Integration file** | `.claude/commands/`, `.claude/hooks/` | `.cursorrules` |
| **Auto-refresh** | Hooks call `bd prime` | Static rules (manual refresh) |
| **Setup complexity** | Multiple files | Single file |
| **Update frequency** | Dynamic (hooks) | Static (updated via `bd setup cursor`) |

title: Implement content-hash based collision resolution for deterministic convergence
description:
The current collision resolution uses creation timestamps to decide which issue to keep vs. remap. This is non-deterministic when two clones create issues at nearly the same time.

Root cause of bd-71107098:
- Clone A creates test-1="Issue from clone A" at T0
- Clone B creates test-1="Issue from clone B" at T0+30ms
- Clone B syncs first, remaps Clone A's to test-2
- Clone A syncs second, sees collision, remaps Clone B's to test-2
- Result: titles are swapped between clones

Solution:
- Use content-based hashing (title + description + priority + type)
- Deterministic winner: always keep issue with lower hash
- Same collision on different clones produces same result (idempotent)

Implementation:
- Modify ScoreCollisions in internal/storage/sqlite/collision.go
- Replace timestamp-based scoring with content hash comparison
- Ensure hash function is stable across platforms

title: Update ready_issues VIEW to use hierarchical blocking
description:
The ready_issues VIEW (schema.go:97-108) uses the OLD blocking logic that doesn't propagate through parent-child hierarchies.

**Problem:**
- GetReadyWork() function now uses recursive CTE with propagation
- But the ready_issues VIEW still uses simple NOT EXISTS check
- Any code using the VIEW will get DIFFERENT results than GetReadyWork()
- This creates inconsistency and confusion

**Impact:**
- Unknown if the VIEW is actually used anywhere in the codebase
- If it is used, it's returning incorrect results (showing children as ready when parent is blocked)

**Solution:**
Either:
1. Update VIEW to match GetReadyWork logic (complex CTE in a view)
2. Drop the VIEW entirely if unused
3. Make VIEW call GetReadyWork as a function (if SQLite supports it)

**Investigation needed:**
Grep for 'ready_issues' to see if the view is actually used.
notes:
**Investigation results:**
Grepped the codebase - the ready_issues VIEW appears in:
- schema.go (definition)
- WORKFLOW.md, DESIGN.md (documentation)
- No actual Go code queries it directly

**Conclusion:** The VIEW is defined but appears UNUSED by actual code. GetReadyWork() function is used instead.

**Recommended solution:** Drop the VIEW entirely to avoid confusion. It serves no purpose if unused and creates a maintenance burden (needs to stay in sync with GetReadyWork logic).

**Alternative:** If we want to keep it for direct SQL access, update the VIEW definition to match the new recursive CTE logic.

title: Add composite index on dependencies(depends_on_id, type)
description:
The hierarchical blocking query does:
JOIN dependencies d ON d.depends_on_id = bt.issue_id
WHERE d.type = 'parent-child'

Currently we only have idx_dependencies_depends_on (line 41 in schema.go), which covers depends_on_id but not the type filter.

**Impact:**
- Query has to scan ALL dependencies for a given depends_on_id, then filter by type
- With 10k+ issues and many dependencies, this could cause slowdowns
- The blocker propagation happens recursively, amplifying the cost

**Solution:**
Add composite index: CREATE INDEX idx_dependencies_depends_on_type ON dependencies(depends_on_id, type)

**Testing:**
Run EXPLAIN QUERY PLAN on GetReadyWork query before/after to verify index usage.

title: Implement content-hash based collision resolution for deterministic convergence
description:
The current collision resolution uses creation timestamps to decide which issue to keep vs. remap. This is non-deterministic when two clones create issues at nearly the same time.

Root cause of bd-71107098:
- Clone A creates test-1="Issue from clone A" at T0
- Clone B creates test-1="Issue from clone B" at T0+30ms
- Clone B syncs first, remaps Clone A's to test-2
- Clone A syncs second, sees collision, remaps Clone B's to test-2
- Result: titles are swapped between clones

Solution:
- Use content-based hashing (title + description + priority + type)
- Deterministic winner: always keep issue with lower hash
- Same collision on different clones produces same result (idempotent)

Implementation:
- Modify ScoreCollisions in internal/storage/sqlite/collision.go
- Replace timestamp-based scoring with content hash comparison
- Ensure hash function is stable across platforms
notes:
Rename detection successfully implemented and tested!

**What was implemented:**
1. Content-hash based rename detection in DetectCollisions
2. When importing JSONL, if an issue has different ID but same content as DB issue, treat as rename
3. Delete old ID and accept new ID from JSONL
4. Added post-import re-export in sync command to flush rename changes
5. Added post-import commit to capture rename changes

**Test results:**
TestTwoCloneCollision now shows full convergence:
- Clone A: test-2="Issue from clone A", test-1="Issue from clone B"
- Clone B: test-1="Issue from clone B", test-2="Issue from clone A"

Both clones have **identical content** (titles match IDs correctly). Only timestamps differ (expected).

**What remains:**
- Test still expects exact JSON match including timestamps
- Could normalize timestamp comparison, but content convergence is the critical success metric
- The two-clone collision workflow now works without data corruption!

title: Widespread double JSON encoding bug in daemon mode RPC calls
description:
Multiple CLI commands had the same double JSON encoding bug found in bd-1048. All commands that called ResolveID via RPC used string(resp.Data) instead of properly unmarshaling the JSON response. This caused IDs to retain JSON quotes ("bd-1048" instead of bd-1048), which then got double-encoded when passed to subsequent RPC calls.

Affected commands:
- bd show (3 instances)
- bd dep add/remove/tree (5 instances)
- bd label add/remove/list (3 instances)
- bd reopen (1 instance)

Root cause: resp.Data is json.RawMessage (already JSON-encoded), so string() conversion preserves quotes.

Fix: Replace all string(resp.Data) with json.Unmarshal(resp.Data, &id) for proper deserialization.

All commands now tested and working correctly with daemon mode.

title: Export deduplication breaks when JSONL and export_hashes table diverge
description:
## Problem

The export deduplication feature (timestamp-only skipping) breaks when the JSONL file and export_hashes table get out of sync, causing exports to skip issues that aren't actually in the file.

## Symptoms

- `bd export` reports "Skipped 128 issue(s) with timestamp-only changes"
- JSONL file only has 38 lines but DB has 149 issues
- export_hashes table has 149 entries
- Auto-import doesn't trigger (hash matches despite missing data)
- Two repos on same commit show different issue counts

## Root Cause

shouldSkipExport() in autoflush.go compares current issue hash with stored export_hashes entry. If they match, it skips export assuming the issue is already in the JSONL.

This assumption fails when:
1. Git operations (pull, reset, checkout) change JSONL without clearing export_hashes
2. Manual JSONL edits or corruption
3. Import operations that modify DB but don't update export_hashes
4. Partial exports that update export_hashes but don't complete

## Impact

- **Critical data loss risk**: Issues appear to be tracked but aren't persisted to git
- Breaks multi-repo sync (root cause of today's debugging session)
- Auto-import fails to detect staleness (hash matches despite missing data)
- Silent data corruption (no error messages, just missing issues)

## Reproduction

1. Have DB with 149 issues, all in export_hashes table
2. Truncate JSONL to 38 lines (simulate git reset or corruption)
3. Run `bd export` - it skips 128 issues
4. JSONL still has only 38 lines but export thinks it succeeded

## Current Workaround

```bash
sqlite3 .beads/beads.db "DELETE FROM export_hashes"
bd export -o .beads/beads.jsonl
```

## Proposed Solutions

**Option 1: Verify JSONL integrity before skipping**
- Count lines in JSONL, compare with export_hashes count
- If mismatch, clear export_hashes and force full export
- Safe but adds I/O overhead

**Option 2: Hash-based JSONL validation**
- Store hash of entire JSONL file in metadata
- Before export, check if JSONL hash matches
- If mismatch, clear export_hashes
- More efficient, detects any JSONL corruption

**Option 3: Disable timestamp-only deduplication**
- Remove the feature entirely
- Always export all issues
- Simplest and safest, but creates larger git commits

**Option 4: Clear export_hashes on git operations**
- Add post-merge hook to clear export_hashes
- Clear on any import operation
- Defensive approach but may over-clear

## Recommended Fix

Combination of Options 2 + 4:
1. Store JSONL file hash in metadata after export
2. Check hash before export, clear export_hashes if mismatch  
3. Clear export_hashes on import operations
4. Add `bd validate` check for JSONL/export_hashes sync

## Files Involved

- cmd/bd/autoflush.go (shouldSkipExport)
- cmd/bd/export.go (export with deduplication)
- internal/storage/sqlite/metadata.go (export_hashes table)
notes:
## Recovery Session (2025-10-29 21:30)

### What Happened
- Created 14 new hash ID issues (bd-f8b764c9 through bd-f8b764c9.1) 
- bd sync appeared to succeed
- Canonical repo (~/src/beads): 162 issues in DB + JSONL âœ“
- Secondary repo (fred/beads): Only 145 issues vs 162 in canonical âœ—
- Both repos on same git commit but different issue counts!

### Bug Manifestation During Recovery

1. **Initial state**: fred/beads had 145 issues, 145 lines in JSONL, 145 export_hashes entries

2. **After git reset --hard origin/main**: 
   - JSONL: 162 lines (from git)
   - DB: 150 issues (auto-import partially worked)
   - Auto-import failed with UNIQUE constraint error

3. **After manual import --resolve-collisions**:
   - DB: 160 issues
   - JSONL: Still 162 lines
   - export_hashes: 159 entries

4. **After bd export**: 
   - **JSONL reduced to 17 lines!** â† The bug in action
   - export_hashes: 159 entries (skipped exporting 142 issues)
   - Silent data loss - no error message

5. **After clearing export_hashes and re-export**:
   - JSONL: 159 lines (missing 3 issues still)
   - DB: 159 issues
   - Still diverged from canonical

### The Bug Loop
Once export_hashes and JSONL diverge:
- Export skips issues already in export_hashes
- But those issues aren't actually in JSONL
- This creates corrupt JSONL with missing issues
- Auto-import can't detect the problem (file hash matches what was exported)
- Data is lost with no error messages

### Recovery Solution
Couldn't break the loop with export alone. Had to:
1. Copy .beads/beads.db from canonical repo
2. Clear export_hashes
3. Full re-export
4. Finally converged to 162 issues

### Key Learnings

1. **The bug is worse than we thought**: It can create corrupt exports (17 lines instead of 162!)

2. **Auto-import can't save you**: Once export is corrupt, auto-import just imports the corrupt data

3. **Silent failure**: No warnings, no errors, just missing issues

4. **Git operations trigger it**: git reset, git pull, etc. change JSONL without clearing export_hashes

5. **Import operations populate export_hashes**: Even manual imports update export_hashes, setting up future export failures

### Immediate Action Required

**DISABLE EXPORT DEDUPLICATION NOW**

This feature is fundamentally broken and causes data loss. Should be disabled until properly fixed.

Quick fix options:
- Set environment variable to disable feature
- Comment out shouldSkipExport check
- Always clear export_hashes before export
- Add validation that DB count == JSONL line count before allowing export

### Long-term Fix

Need Option 2 + 4 from proposed solutions:
1. Store JSONL file hash after every successful export
2. Before export, verify JSONL hash matches expected
3. If mismatch, log WARNING and clear export_hashes
4. Clear export_hashes on every import operation
5. Add git post-merge hook to clear export_hashes
6. Add `bd validate` command to detect divergence

title: Optimize GetReadyWork performance - 752ms on 10K database (target: <50ms)
notes:
# Performance Analysis (10K Issue Database)

Analyzed using CPU profiles from benchmark suite on Apple M2 Pro.

## Operation Performance

| Operation                        | Time    | Allocations | Memory |
|----------------------------------|---------|-------------|--------|
| bd ready (GetReadyWork)          | ~752ms  | 167,466     | 16MB   |
| bd list (SearchIssues no filter) | ~11.6ms | 89,214      | 5.8MB  |
| bd list (SearchIssues filtered)  | ~9.2ms  | 62,365      | 3.5MB  |
| bd create (CreateIssue)          | ~2.6ms  | 146         | 8.6KB  |
| bd update (UpdateIssue)          | ~0.32ms | 364         | 15KB   |
| bd close (UpdateIssue)           | ~0.32ms | 364         | 15KB   |

**Target: <50ms for all operations on 10K database**

**Current issue: GetReadyWork is 15x over target (752ms vs 50ms)**

## Root Cause

GetReadyWork (internal/storage/sqlite/ready.go:90-128) uses recursive CTE to propagate blocking:
- 65x slower than SearchIssues
- Recalculates entire blocked issue tree on every call
- Algorithm:
  1. Find directly blocked issues via 'blocks' dependencies
  2. Recursively propagate blockage to descendants (max depth: 50)
  3. Exclude all blocked issues from results

## CPU Profile Analysis

- Database syscalls (pthread_cond_signal, syscall6): ~75%
- SQLite engine overhead: inherent to recursive CTE
- Application code (query construction): <1%

**Bottleneck is the recursive CTE query execution, not application code.**

## Optimization Recommendations

### High Impact (Likely to achieve <50ms target)

1. **Cache blocked issue calculation**
   - Add `blocked_issues` table updated on dependency changes
   - Trade write complexity for read speed (ready called >> dependency changes)
   - Eliminates recursive CTE on every read

2. **Add/verify database indexes**
   ```sql
   CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_dependencies_blocked 
     ON dependencies(issue_id, type, depends_on_id);
   CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS idx_issues_status 
     ON issues(status);
   ```

### Medium Impact

3. **Reduce allocations** (167K allocations for GetReadyWork)
   - Profile `scanIssues()` for object pooling opportunities
   - Reuse slice capacity for repeated calls

### Low Impact (Not recommended)
- Query optimization for CRUD operations (already <3ms)
- Connection pooling tuning (not showing in profiles)

## Verification

Run benchmarks to validate optimization:
```bash
make bench-quick
go tool pprof -http=:8080 internal/storage/sqlite/bench-cpu-*.prof
```

Profile files automatically generated in `internal/storage/sqlite/`.

title: AI-supervised database migrations for safer schema evolution
description:
## Problem

Database migrations can lose user data through edge cases that are hard to anticipate (e.g., GH #201 where bd migrate failed to set issue_prefix, or bd-d355a07d false positive data loss warnings). Since beads is designed to be run by AI agents, we should leverage AI to make migrations safer.

## Current State

Migrations run blindly with:
- No pre-flight validation
- No data integrity verification
- No rollback on failure
- Limited post-migration testing

Recent issues:
- GH #201: Migration didn't set issue_prefix config, breaking commands
- bd-d355a07d: False positive "data loss" warnings on collision resolution
- Users reported migration data loss (fixed but broader problem remains)

## Proposal: AI-Supervised Migration Framework

Use AI to supervise migrations through structured verification:

### 1. Pre-Migration Analysis
- AI reads migration code and current schema
- Identifies potential data loss scenarios
- Generates validation queries to verify assumptions
- Creates snapshot queries for before/after comparison

### 2. Migration Execution
- Take database backup/snapshot
- Run validation queries (pre-state)
- Execute migration in transaction
- Run validation queries (post-state)

### 3. Post-Migration Verification
- AI compares pre/post snapshots
- Verifies data integrity invariants
- Checks for unexpected data loss
- Validates config completeness (like issue_prefix)

### 4. Rollback on Anomalies
- If AI detects data loss, rollback transaction
- Present human-readable error report
- Suggest fix before retrying

## Example Flow

```
$ bd migrate

â†’ Analyzing migration plan...
â†’ AI identified 3 potential data loss scenarios
â†’ Generating validation queries...
â†’ Creating pre-migration snapshot...
â†’ Running migration in transaction...
â†’ Verifying post-migration state...
âœ“ All 247 issues accounted for
âœ“ Config table complete (issue_prefix: "mcp")
âœ“ Dependencies intact (342 relationships verified)
â†’ Migration successful!
```

If something goes wrong:
```
$ bd migrate

â†’ Analyzing migration plan...
â†’ AI identified issue: Missing issue_prefix config after migration
â†’ Recommendation: Add prefix detection step
â†’ Aborting migration - database unchanged
```

## Implementation Ideas

### A. Migration Validator Tool
Create `bd migrate --validate` that:
- Simulates migration on copy of database
- Uses AI to verify data integrity
- Reports potential issues before real migration

### B. Migration Test Generator
AI generates test cases for migrations:
- Edge cases (empty DB, large DB, missing config)
- Data integrity checks
- Regression tests

### C. Migration Invariants
Define invariants that AI checks:
- Issue count should not decrease (unless collision resolution)
- All required config keys present
- Foreign key relationships intact
- No orphaned dependencies

### D. Self-Healing Migrations
AI detects incomplete migrations and suggests fixes:
- Missing config values (like GH #201)
- Orphaned data
- Index inconsistencies

## Benefits

1. **Catch edge cases**: AI explores scenarios humans miss
2. **Self-documenting**: AI explains what migration does
3. **Agent-friendly**: Agents can run migrations confidently
4. **Fewer rollbacks**: Detect issues before committing
5. **Better testing**: AI generates comprehensive test suites

## Open Questions

1. Which AI model? (Fast: Haiku, Thorough: Sonnet/GPT-4)
2. How to balance safety vs migration speed?
3. Should AI validation be required or optional?
4. How to handle offline scenarios (no API access)?
5. What invariants should always be checked?

## Related Work

- bd-b245: Migration registry (makes migrations introspectable)
- GH #201: issue_prefix migration bug (motivating example)
- bd-d355a07d: False positive data loss warnings
acceptance_criteria:
Phase 1: Migration invariants implemented and tested, checked after every migration, clear error messages when invariants fail.

Phase 2: Snapshot capture before migrations, comparison after, rollback on verification failure.

Phase 3 (stretch): AI validation optional flag implemented, AI can analyze migration code and generate custom validation queries.

Phase 4 (stretch): Migration test fixtures created, all fixtures pass migrations, CI runs migration tests.

CRDT-based architecture for guaranteed convergence (v2.0)
description:
## Vision
Redesign beads around Conflict-Free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs) to provide mathematical guarantees for N-way collision resolution at arbitrary scale.

## Current Limitations
- Content-hash based collision resolution fails at 5+ clones
- Non-deterministic convergence in multi-round scenarios
- UNIQUE constraint violations during rename operations
- No formal proof of convergence properties

## CRDT Benefits
- Provably convergent (Strong Eventual Consistency)
- Commutative/Associative/Idempotent operations
- No coordination required between clones
- Scales to 100+ concurrent workers
- Well-understood mathematical foundations

## Proposed Architecture

### 1. UUID-Based IDs
Replace sequential IDs with UUIDs:
- Current: bd-1c63eb84, bd-9063acda, bd-4d80b7b1
- CRDT: bd-a1b2c3d4-e5f6-7890-abcd-ef1234567890
- Human aliases maintained separately: #42 maps to UUID

### 2. Last-Write-Wins (LWW) Elements
Each field becomes an LWW register:

title: Export deduplication breaks when JSONL and export_hashes table diverge
description:
## Problem

The export deduplication feature (timestamp-only skipping) breaks when the JSONL file and export_hashes table get out of sync, causing exports to skip issues that aren't actually in the file.

## Symptoms

- `bd export` reports "Skipped 128 issue(s) with timestamp-only changes"
- JSONL file only has 38 lines but DB has 149 issues
- export_hashes table has 149 entries
- Auto-import doesn't trigger (hash matches despite missing data)
- Two repos on same commit show different issue counts

## Root Cause

shouldSkipExport() in autoflush.go compares current issue hash with stored export_hashes entry. If they match, it skips export assuming the issue is already in the JSONL.

This assumption fails when:
1. Git operations (pull, reset, checkout) change JSONL without clearing export_hashes
2. Manual JSONL edits or corruption
3. Import operations that modify DB but don't update export_hashes
4. Partial exports that update export_hashes but don't complete

## Impact

- **Critical data loss risk**: Issues appear to be tracked but aren't persisted to git
- Breaks multi-repo sync (root cause of today's debugging session)
- Auto-import fails to detect staleness (hash matches despite missing data)
- Silent data corruption (no error messages, just missing issues)

## Reproduction

1. Have DB with 149 issues, all in export_hashes table
2. Truncate JSONL to 38 lines (simulate git reset or corruption)
3. Run `bd export` - it skips 128 issues
4. JSONL still has only 38 lines but export thinks it succeeded

## Current Workaround

```bash
sqlite3 .beads/beads.db "DELETE FROM export_hashes"
bd export -o .beads/beads.jsonl
```

## Proposed Solutions

**Option 1: Verify JSONL integrity before skipping**
- Count lines in JSONL, compare with export_hashes count
- If mismatch, clear export_hashes and force full export
- Safe but adds I/O overhead

**Option 2: Hash-based JSONL validation**
- Store hash of entire JSONL file in metadata
- Before export, check if JSONL hash matches
- If mismatch, clear export_hashes
- More efficient, detects any JSONL corruption

**Option 3: Disable timestamp-only deduplication**
- Remove the feature entirely
- Always export all issues
- Simplest and safest, but creates larger git commits

**Option 4: Clear export_hashes on git operations**
- Add post-merge hook to clear export_hashes
- Clear on any import operation
- Defensive approach but may over-clear

## Recommended Fix

Combination of Options 2 + 4:
1. Store JSONL file hash in metadata after export
2. Check hash before export, clear export_hashes if mismatch  
3. Clear export_hashes on import operations
4. Add `bd validate` check for JSONL/export_hashes sync

## Files Involved

- cmd/bd/autoflush.go (shouldSkipExport)
- cmd/bd/export.go (export with deduplication)
- internal/storage/sqlite/metadata.go (export_hashes table)
